body.p:
Your letter did not reach me: till tonight, when I was getting ready to go to New York:
else I wd would have hastened to your "Den" & drank to our noble selves in the promised sour mash.
I have been a little-worried lately over things in general & in some sense, at beginning life over again, else I wd would not have jumped so quick at your ill-treatment of me.

God knows & Walt knows that I am as
slow as the wrath of God—to take offense especially at what my friends do or say. Life in the main, has taught me as Bailey says
body.l: And all mortality can teach is—Bear"!
body.p: (2) To start right again I think you had better send me my MSS—and let me do as I d—m please with it . . I will send it to the World
Will see you as soon as I get back from N.Y. . .
Remember that the friend most solicitous of your welfare at the "Scovel House" has always been the undersigned—

postscript.p: I shall never allude to the "old son" again!
